question: Question 6-05/13/2002 A reactor startup is in progress by withdrawing a control rod and then waiting until count rate stabilizes. The reactor is not critical. Assume that the control rod is being withdrawn in equal amounts each time and each control rod withdrawal adds equivalent amounts of reactivity. Compare two consecutive control rod withdrawals.

answers.answer: a. Time for power to stabilize will be equal for both withdrawals and the power increase will be the same for both withdrawals.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Chapt. 5, pp. 5-1 — 5-28.

answers.answer: b. The power increase will be the same for both withdrawals but the time for power to stabilize will be less for the second withdrawal.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Chapt. 5, pp. 5-1 — 5-28.

answers.answer: c. The power increase will be the same for both withdrawals but time for power to stabilize will be longer for the second withdrawal.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Chapt. 5, pp. 5-1 — 5-28.

answers.answer: d. The power increase will be larger for the second withdrawal and the time for power to stabilize will be longer for the second withdrawal.
answers.feedback: Correct.

question: Question 7-05/13/2002 Which one of the following is the PRINCIPAL reason for operating with thermal neutrons instead of fast neutrons?

answers.answer: a. Reactors operating primarily on fast neutrons are inherently unstable and cannot be easily controlled at low power.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reactor Operating Training Manual, Unit 5

answers.answer: b. The fission cross section of the fuel is much higher for thermal neutrons than for fast neutrons.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: c. Doppler and moderator temperature coefficients become positive as neutrons energy increases.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reactor Operating Training Manual, Unit 5

answers.answer: d. Increased neutron efficient since thermal neutrons are less likely to leak out of the core than fast neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reactor Operating Training Manual, Unit 5

question: Question 8-05/13/2002 Assume that reactor power is 50% and equilibrium Xenon is attained. Reactor power is then increased to 100%. Which one of the following correctly describes the new equilibrium Xenon value?

answers.answer: a. The 100% equilibrium xenon is half the 50% value
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 8.2-8.4, pp. 8-3.

answers.answer: b. The 100% equilibrium xenon is equal to the 50% value.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 8.2-8.4, pp. 8-3.

answers.answer: c. The 100% equilibrium xenon is higher than the 50% value but not twice as high.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: d. The 100% equilibrium xenon is twice as high as the 50% value.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 8.2-8.4, pp. 8-3.

question: Question 12-05/13/2002 Which one of the following is the primary reason a neutron source is installed in the core?

answers.answer: a. To allow for testing and irradiation experiments when the reactor is shutdown.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 5.2 (b), p. 5-4.

answers.answer: b. To supply the neutrons required to start the chain reaction for subsequent reactor startups.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 5.2 (b), p. 5-4.

answers.answer: c. To provide a neutron level high enough to be monitored for a controlled reactor startup.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: d. To increase the excess reactivity of the reactor which reduces the frequency for refueling.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 5.2 (b), p. 5-4.

question: Question 18-05/13/2002 Following a scram, the value of the stable reactor period is:

answers.answer: a. approximately 50 seconds, because the rate of negative reactivity insertion rapidly approaches zero.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 4.6, p. 4-16.

answers.answer: b. approximately -10 seconds, as determined by the rate of decay of the shortest lived delayed neutron

answers.answer: c. approximately -80 seconds, as determined by the rate of decay of the longest lived delayed neutron precursors.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: d. infinity, since neutron production has been terminated.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 4.6, p. 4-16.

question: Question 20-05/13/2002 Which one of the following is the definition of Shutdown Margin?

answers.answer: a. The overall condition where the reactor is shutdown, the console key switch is off, and no work in progress involving fuel or experiments.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: T.S. Definitions

answers.answer: b. The reactor can be made subcritical by at least $0.25 in a cold xenon-free condition, with the most reactive rod full out, and all samples in their most reactive positions.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: T.S. Definitions

answers.answer: c. The condition where all control rods are fully inserted or reactivity condition equivalent to one where all control rods are fully inserted.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: T.S. Definitions

answers.answer: d. The minimum shutdown reactivity necessary to ensure that the reactor can be made subcritical by means of the control and safety systems, from any operating conditions and will remain subcritical without further operator action.
answers.feedback: Correct.
